Please telegraph sanction to Controller Stationery Calcutta for Gestetner Duplicator item 714 1938-39 Stationery Office Price List to be sent here. - POLITICAL -\ / The Hon’ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf presents his com pliments to The Political Agent, Bahrain, and has the honour to transmit to him a copy of the undermentioned docu ment (*). British Consulate-General, BUSHIRE. Bahrain. Dated... September .1939. -vf. : ~jtT‘ — Reference to prt‘viou§^em’mspondence : itT j Bahrain telegram No.360 dated the 6th September 193^- Description of Enclosure. Name and Date Subject. Residency telegram No. Gestetner duplicator for 462 dated the 8th September Bahrain. 1939.Telegram ]?rom I.W.C To No.462. Dated the Political Hesident, Bushire. Controller of Stationery, Calcutta. 8th September 1939. One Geatetner duplicator item No.714 1938-1939 Stationery Office Price Liat indented for by Political Agent, Bahrain, aanctioned. Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.Telegram From To No. En Clair Political, Bahrain Controller of Stationery, 7 Calcutta. 185 Dated the 12th September 1939. You^r telegram TW1968 September 2nd and Resident’s telegram 462 September 8th. Please supply with GESTETNER duplicator 12 tubes ink item 752. 12 quires waxless stencil paper item 755. Two styless pens item 745. 24 reams duplicating paper semi-absorbent item.244 or other cheap paper for use with Gestetner. Correcting fluid two bottles. - POLITIC All AGENT -(INDIA) LIMITED 11 KOTHARI CHAMBERS » v {J f M c L E 6 D ROAD I ' ) Karachi September 2, 1939. h \ \ Thank you for witnessing a demonstration of the Gestetner 66. 7/e have pleasure in confirming our verbal quotation as under:- One, 'Gestetner 66'. Foolscap size. Autotaatic Fee^. Special price....fc. 920 • 0. (f. o. b. Bahrain.) Nett. Main improved features of the Gestetner 66, which were shewn at the demonstration, are briefly outlined below. The Gestetner is a clean and simple duplicator to handle. Ink distribution is even and automatic. Colour change can be affected in a few minutes. Being fully enclosed, dust, grit and moisture are excluded from its mechanism. Its life is thus considerably prolonged. ^ ^ Gestetner 66 is fitted with an improved, self-adjusting push type feed, which automatically adjusts its grip to paper of any thickness. Accurate registration is also obtained. It is protected against accidental damage by a metal cover. The feed-board accommodates 500 sheets of paper. Being an integral part of the machine, it cannot be damaged or mislaid. A recording counter is fitted, which can be set to count the number of copies printed. This will be found of considerable value in reproducing work of a confidential nature. The Gestetner 66 will, automatical]y, feed-in, print, count and deliver anyt Page TWO, number of copies required, at a speed of, approximately, two to three thousand copies per hour. The Gestetner is fully guaranteed by us A few specimens of work, reproduced on the Gestetner, are attached. Awaiting further instructions. Yours faithfull; D. This insurance attaches from the time the goods leave the Warehouse and/or Store at the place named m the policy; for the commencement of the transit and continues durina the ordinary course of trans.it. including customary transhipment if any, until the goods are discharged overside from t he overseas vessel at the final port. Thereafter the insurance conti nues whilst the goods are In transit and/or awaiting transit until delivered to final warehouse at the destination named iri the policy or until the expiry of 15 days (or 30 days if the destination to which the goods are insured is outside the limits of the port) whichever shall first occur The tune limits referred to abo ve to be reckoned from midnight of the day on which the discharge overside of the goods hereb y insured from the overseas vessel is completed. Held covered «t a premium to be arranged ifl the event of transhipment, if any, other than as above and/or in the event of delay m excess of th,e above time limits arising from circumstances beyond the control of the Assured. , 2. Including transit by r'traft, raft and/or lighter to and from the vessel. Each craft raff and/or lighter to be deemed >a separate insurance. The Assured are not to be preiudiced bv at>» agreement exempting lighte.-rmen from liability. preiuoicea oy any 3. Held covered at a premium to be arranged in case of deviation or change of vovage or other variation of the adven ture by reason of the exercise of any liberty granted to the shino wner or charterer under the contract of affreightment, or of any omission or error in ,he de.cn ? pTion of the interest vessel or voyvsge. 4. In the event of the exer.pise of any liberty granted to the shipowner or charterer under the contract of affreightment whe reby such contract is terminated at a port or place other than the destination named therein, the? goods are held covered in terms of the policy at a premium to he arranged until sold and delivered at such port or place, or notice be given to Underwriters to terminate the policy whichever first occurs; or, if the goods be forwarded to th- destinatiou named herein or to any other destination, until arrival at destination (subject to the provisions of Clause 1 as to the period covetred after discharge overside from the overseas vessel Bt 'fiVli port); provided always that no ^ability shall attach to this policy for loss or damage occurring after the termination of such Contract of affreightment and Proximately caused by deUv «? inlierent vice or nature of the subject matter insured. y ueiay or 5. Warranted free from averag e under the percentage specified in the policy, unless general nr the vessel or craft be stranded, sun'k or burnt, but notwithstanding this warranty the Underwriter! Clause) be reinstated in this Policy by deletion of the said Clause, or should the risks or any of them mentioned in the same Clause or the risks of mines torpedoes bombs or other engines of tear be insured under this Policy, then notwithstanding anything in this Policy to the contrary, (•) the insurance against the said risks shall not attach to the interest hereby insured or to any part thereof (i) prior to being on board an overseas vessel. [For the purpose of this Clause 3 n» overseas vessel shall be deemed to mean a vessel carrying the interest from one port or place to another where such voyage involves a sea passage by that vessel) |M9>m 91 » enl nl nlo Jaw (ii) after being discharged overside from the final /unt of discharge overseas vessel at :tu09 s Li rfri after expiry of IS days counting from midnight of the day on which the overseas vessel is safely anchored or moored at the final port of discharge, whichever shall first occur, (iii) at a port or place of transhipment to another overseas vessel after expiry of 15 days {counting from midnight of the day on which the overseas vessel entering with the interest is safely anchored or moored) until the interest is on board the on-carrying overseas vessel. In the event of the exercise of any liberty granted to the Shipowner or Charterer under the contract of affreightment whereby such contract is terminated at a i>ort or place other than the destination named therein such port or place shall be deemed the final port of discharge for the purpose of this Clause 3. Stationer,, Calckta A-' * * TELEPHONE: m REGENT No. Spt-4783 To IH 3, CHURCH LANE, CALCUTTA Dated 19 The Publicity Officer, Persian Gulf, Bahrain. ^0 f D bl11 Ho * 8365 dat ed the 23rd October 1940 for Rs. 92-4-0, representing the cost of the papers supplied to you in compliance with Express letter No. 1511-17/18 AUg i*!^ 1940 from the Political Agent, Bahrain, is submitted herewith# An early payment is requested. / J.G. 23/10.The Bahrein Petroleum Company Limited A w a 1 1, Bahrein Island, Persian Gulf. January 3, 1943, PA-633 FILS #600.15 H. B. M’s Political Agent, Bahrein. Dear Sir, ^ m E We acknowledge your letter 2329/-17/181 dated 3lst December 1942 in which you request a replacement Silk Carrier for Gestetner Rotary Dupli- Unfortunately our stock of these carriers is almost exhausted and we find replacements of these and all Gestetner parts exceedingly difficult to obtain. Our last order on Bombay in August 1941 was not filled and in this connection we quote an extract from a letter written to us by Messrs. Caltex (India) Ltd. at that time. 'Regarding the balance of your requisition we are informed that they (Messrs. Gestetner (India) Ltd.) have no stock of the items called for in India and that if an order is placed with them, they will have to order the goods from their Works in England'. We reordered from London in September 1941 and the material was not received here until June 1942. We are sure you will appreciate that whilst we are anxious to assist, for the present, conditions make it impossible for us to supply this May we suggest that possibly a thin gauze or light open-woven fabric of silk or cotton would serve fairly satisfactorily for a time and might be obtained locally. cator. item Yours very trul W. P. ANDERSON, CHIEF LOCAL REPRESENTATIVE, THE BAHREIN PETROLEUM COMPANY LIMITED cc. Acctg.

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the volume.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 74; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-65; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: This file concerns the Bahrain Political Agency's purchase of a Gestetner duplicating machine, plus accessories. The file also contains correspondence regarding the shipping of stationery from the Government of India's central stationery office in Calcutta to the Political Agency at Bahrain.The file contains samples of items printed on a Gestetner machine, including a copy of the front cover of an official report of the proceedings of the Sind Legislative Assembly, dated 4 March 1938.Correspondents include the following: the Political Agent, Bahrain; the Deputy Controller of Stationery, Calcutta; the Assistant Controller of Stationery, Calcutta; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire; Gestetner Limited; the Publicity Officer, Persian Gulf, Bahrain.

name.namePart: Government of India, Controller of Printing, Stationery and Stamps
Public Relations Officer, Persian Gulf, Bahrain
